Raymie pointed out an interesting possibility in design comments a while
back: that DNS lookups that occur during the crawl could be handled as
just another kind of crawled URI.

There's a URI format for representing DNS lookups:

http://www.ietf.org/internet-drafts/draft-josefsson-dns-url-07.txt

...and both binary and text formats for storing the results of
DNS lookup:

http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2540.txt

So when first considering any HTTP URI for crawling, we'd note
that we haven't yet done a DNS lookup, and generate a DNS lookup
URI that will be fetched as a precondition of fetching the 
HTTP URI. 

This DNS URI could be passed to the front of the normal queues
in much the same way robots.txt preconditions or embedded-image
rapid-followups will be. The results of the DNS lookup would be
logged into the same archival files as HTTP results. 

This would also challenge us early-on to make the main worker-thread
loop capable of handling non-HTTP URIs in a sensible way. We
might find the same retry policies can apply across different
protocols, or that custom retry policies are necessary.

Reddy, I'd like you to update your "DNS Revisit" plans to take
into account this approach. We can discuss in the call tonight.

- Gordon
